Package edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.graph

Class StateGraph

java.lang.Object
edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.graph.StateGraph
All Implemented Interfaces:
Serializable
public class StateGraph extends Object implements Serializable
A state graph is made up of nodes which are world states that are liked by two kinds of edges: epistemic edges that define what each character believes the world state to be, and temporal edges that define how the world state changes as a result of an event.

From every node there extends exactly one epistemic edge for each character. In other words, these graphs cannot model characters with uncertain beliefs. Characters must always commit to a belief about every fluent, but those beliefs may be wrong. This requirement also implies that these graphs represent an arbitrarily nested theory of mind (what x believes y believes, and so on).

The graph does not contain duplicate nodes; in other words, the graph will never have two nodes which represent exactly the same world state. When adding edges to the graph, if the edge would create a new node which is a duplicate of an existing node, this is detected, and the original node is used instead. A graph can be (and often is) infinite, meaning that there are always more nodes which could be added to it by adding more temporal edges; however, adding a single temporal edge to the graph will always add only a finite number of new nodes and edges. This means that state graphs are an implementation of the finite state interface. In other words, every individual world state in the graph can always be represented by a finite number of nodes.

Planning can be done directly in a state graph if the overhead of detecting duplicate nodes is acceptable. State graphs are also useful for representing the true initial state of a problem as a finite structure if any triggers apply in the initial state originally defined by the problem, since applying triggers can lead to an initial state which cannot be represented as a finite proposition.

Author:
Stephen G. Ware

  • Field Details

    • fluents

      public final ImmutableSet<Fluent> fluents
      The set of all fluents tracked by the state nodes in this graph (with all Fluent.characters removed). This set contains only non-espitemic fluents; to check the value of an epistemic fluent at a node, follow epistemic edges for the characters in order from that node and check the value of the fluent minus all characters in the final destination node.

    • characters

      public final ImmutableSet<Character> characters
      The set of all characters whose beliefs are represented in this graph

    • triggers

      public final EventSet<Trigger> triggers
      The set of all ground triggers which can occur in the states represented in this graph

    • root

      public final StateNode root
      The first state represented by this graph (usually a problem's initial state)

  • Constructor Details

    • StateGraph

      public StateGraph(ImmutableSet<? extends Fluent> fluents, ImmutableSet<Character> characters, EventSet<? extends Trigger> triggers, FiniteState root)
      Constructs a new state graph that tracks a given set of fluents, characters, and triggers, and which starts with a given state.
      Parameters:
      fluents - the set of all fluents to be tracked by the state nodes in this graph
      characters - the set of all characters whose beliefs are to be represented in this graph
      triggers - the set of all ground triggers which can occur in the states represented by this graph
      root - the first state to be represented by this graph (usually but not necessarily the initial state of a planning problem

    • StateGraph

      public StateGraph(CompiledProblem problem)
      Constructs a new state graph based on a compiled planning problem. The fluent tracked in this graph will be all fluent defined by the problem. The characters tracked in this graph will be all characters defined by the problem's universe. The triggers tracked will be all trigger defined by the problem. The root state will be the problem's initial state.
      Parameters:
      problem - the compiled planning problem
